BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: More small and, in isolated cases, medium-sized moist snow slides and avalanches are possible. Weak layers in the old snowpack can be released especially by large additional loads on shady slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of warming during the day more small and medium-sized moist snow slides and avalanches are possible below approximately 2600 m, in the event of solar radiation in particular on rocky slopes.
Weak layers in the old snowpack can be released in isolated cases by people on very steep shady slopes, in particular in the vicinity of peaks above approximately 2500 m. The avalanche prone locations are rather rare but are difficult to recognise.
There is a danger of falling on the hard snow surface. This applies in particular in the early morning.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The conditions are wintry at high altitude. Individual weak layers exist in the snowpack on shady slopes. Adjacent to ridgelines hardly any snow is lying.
Low and intermediate altitudes and very steep sunny slopes: The conditions are spring-like.
In all altitude zones less snow than usual is lying.
Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise as the day progresses to increasing softening of the snowpack in particular on steep southeast, south and southwest facing slopes below approximately 2500 m.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The weather conditions will foster a gradual strengthening of the snowpack.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Weak layers in the upper part of the snowpack necessitate caution. In addition a latent danger of gliding avalanches exists.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Weak layers in the upper part of the snowpack can still be released in isolated cases by individual winter sport participants. This applies in particular on very steep sunny slopes above approximately 2600 m. Avalanches can reach large size in isolated cases.

Individual gliding avalanches are possible, even large ones in isolated cases. This applies in particular on steep grassy slopes below approximately 2600 m. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.

The somewhat older wind slabs are now only very rarely prone to triggering. Individual avalanche prone locations are to be found on very steep shady slopes above approximately 2600 m. This applies in particular adjacent to ridgelines.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Faceted weak layers exist in the top section of the snowpack, in particular on very steep sunny slopes above approximately 2600 m. Towards its base, the snowpack is largely stable.
Low and intermediate altitudes:
The old snowpack is wet and its surface has a melt-freeze crust that is strong in many cases. The high temperatures as the day progresses will give rise to slight moistening of the snowpack. This applies on very steep sunny slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The avalanche danger will decrease gradually. Weak layers in the upper part of the snowpack necessitate caution. In addition a latent danger of gliding avalanches exists.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Weak layers in the old snowpack can be released in some places by people on shady slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Very early morning: There is a danger of falling on the hard snow surface.
On very steep shady slopes the avalanches can be triggered in the old snow and reach medium size. This applies in particular in case of a large load.
As a consequence of warming during the day more small and medium-sized moist snow slides and avalanches are possible below approximately 2600 m, caution is to be exercised in particular in steep rocky terrain.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The conditions are wintry at high altitude. In particular adjacent to ridgelines snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind.
Individual weak layers exist in the top section of the snowpack on shady slopes.
Low and intermediate altitudes and very steep sunny slopes: The conditions are spring-like. The surface of the snowpack has frozen to form a strong crust and will soften during the day.
In all regions as well as in all altitude zones less snow than usual is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The avalanche danger is within the lower range of danger level 2 (moderate).

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The fresh and older wind slabs must be evaluated with care and prudence on very steep shady slopes at high altitude. As the day progresses, a few moist snow slides are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The no longer entirely fresh wind slabs can be released in isolated cases, but mostly only by large additional loads,, especially at their margins. They are to be found in particular on very steep shady slopes and adjacent to ridgelines. Mostly avalanches are small.
As a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation more mostly small wet loose snow avalanches are possible below approximately 2500 m, in particular on steep east, south and west facing slopes in all altitude zones. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
High altitudes and the high Alpine regions: The somewhat older wind slabs are lying on soft layers. They are in individual cases still prone to triggering.
Towards its base, the snowpack consists of faceted crystals. The snowpack will be subject to considerable local variations above the tree line.
Intermediate and high altitudes: The snowpack is moist and its surface has a melt-freeze crust that is strong in many cases, in particular on sunny slopes. During the day: The high temperatures will give rise to increasing moistening of the snowpack, in particular on sunny slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The avalanche danger will persist. Wet snow requires caution.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Outgoing longwave radiation during the night was good. Wind slabs above approximately 2500 m.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The surface of the snowpack has frozen to form a strong crust and will soften during the day. The hard wind slabs of recent weeks can be released by a single winter sport participant in isolated cases on northeast to north to northwest facing aspects above approximately 2500 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The old snowpack will be generally well bonded. Weak layers exist in the top section of the old snowpack especially on very steep shady slopes.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The mostly small wind slabs of last week must be evaluated with care and prudence.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The snowpack will be subject to considerable local variations over a wide area. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls at intermediate and high altitudes. The wind slabs can be released, especially by large additional loads, on steep shady slopes at elevated altitudes.
In particular on steep slopes individual avalanches are possible as a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The wind slabs are lying on weak layers.
In steep terrain there is a danger of falling on the hard snow surface.
The solar radiation will give rise as the day progresses to moistening of the snowpack in some places.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The weather will be mild over a wide area.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The backcountry touring conditions in the morning, after a clear night, are mostly favourable.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Even in moderately steep terrain there is a danger of falling on the hard snow surface.
The hard wind slabs are rather small and can only be released in isolated cases. Transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack where hard layers are lying on a weakly bonded old snowpack are unfavourable. Such avalanche prone locations are rather rare. Skiers can release avalanches only in isolated cases.
Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise as the day progresses to slight moistening of the snowpack. Until the temperature falls only isolated mostly small moist and wet avalanches are possible below approximately 2600 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The weather was mild. Above the tree line snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind.
Especially on steep sunny slopes as well as below approximately 2200 m less snow than usual is lying. Also adjacent to ridgelines hardly any snow is lying.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Individual avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular in high Alpine regions. Moist snow slides and avalanches are still possible.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of warming during the day more mostly small moist snow slides and avalanches are possible below approximately 2600 m, in the event of solar radiation in particular on rocky slopes.
Weak layers in the old snowpack can be released in very isolated cases by people on very steep shady slopes, in particular in the vicinity of peaks above approximately 2500 m. The avalanche prone locations are very rare but are difficult to recognise.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
In the Prealps as well as at low altitude no snow is lying. Also along the border with France less snow than usual is lying.
Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise as the day progresses to slight moistening of the snowpack in particular on steep southeast, south and southwest facing slopes below approximately 2500 m.
In very isolated cases weak layers exist in the centre of the snowpack on steep shady slopes.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wet snow represents the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: As a consequence of warming individual mostly small moist snow slides and avalanches are possible above approximately 2000 m. Caution is to be exercised in particular in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain, as well as on very steep sunny slopes. In steep terrain there is a danger of falling on the icy crust.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The old snowpack remains subject to considerable local variations. At intermediate altitudes hardly any snow is lying. In high Alpine regions a little snow is lying. In gullies and bowls the wind slabs are larger. These are to be found especially at high altitude. The weather conditions will give rise to significant moistening of the snowpack also at high altitude.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The conditions are favourable over a wide area.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The somewhat older wind slabs can still be released in some cases in particular on very steep shady slopes above approximately 2600 m. Caution is to be exercised in particular adjacent to ridgelines in high Alpine regions. Mostly the avalanches are small.

Only isolated gliding avalanches are possible, in particular on steep east, south and west facing slopes below approximately 2600 m. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
High altitudes and the high Alpine regions:
The somewhat older wind slabs are lying on soft layers. They are in individual cases still prone to triggering.
Towards its base, the snowpack consists of faceted crystals. The snowpack will be subject to considerable local variations above the tree line.

Intermediate and high altitudes: Early and late morning: The snowpack is wet and its surface has a melt-freeze crust that is strong in many cases, in particular on sunny slopes. During the day: The high temperatures will give rise to slight moistening of the snowpack, in particular on sunny slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The backcountry touring conditions are spring-like.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Individual avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular in high Alpine regions.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Very early morning: In steep terrain there is a danger of falling on the icy crust.
As a consequence of warming during the day more mostly small moist snow slides and avalanches are possible below approximately 2600 m. This applies in particular in steep rocky terrain.
Weak layers in the old snowpack can be released in very isolated cases by winter sport participants in particular on very steep shady slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The snowpack is largely stable. Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise as the day progresses to gradual softening of the snowpack below approximately 2500 m.
On sunny slopes as well as at low altitude no snow is lying. Also in high Alpine regions only a small amount of snow is lying for the time of year.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The mostly small wind slabs of last week must be evaluated with care and prudence.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The wind slabs can be released, especially by large additional loads,. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls and adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas. As a consequence of warming, the likelihood of natural moist avalanches being released will increase gradually in particular on steep sunny slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise as the day progresses to moistening of the snowpack.
In steep terrain there is a danger of falling on the hard snow surface.
Below approximately 1600 m only a little snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The weather will be mild over a wide area.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The surface of the snowpack has frozen to form a strong crust and will soften during the day.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The old snowpack will be generally well bonded.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Continuous warming. Outgoing longwave radiation during the night will be reduced.
Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise as the day progresses to increasing moistening of the snowpack. Small moist and wet avalanches are possible below approximately 2400 m. This applies in particular in gullies and bowls in particular above approximately 1500 m, as well as on steep sunny slopes. Restraint should be exercised because avalanches can sweep people along and give rise to falls.
The hard wind slabs are easy to recognise but can be released in isolated cases. The avalanche prone locations are to be found also in places that are some distance from ridgelines and in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. Skiers can release avalanches in isolated cases, including medium-sized ones.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: More recent wind slabs can be released easily, even by a single winter sport participant, above approximately 1900 m, especially at their margins. The spring-like weather conditions gave rise to moistening of the snowpack below approximately 2400 m. Snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind. Weak layers in the old snowpack necessitate caution and restraint.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The backcountry touring conditions in the morning, after a clear night, are mostly favourable.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Even in moderately steep terrain there is a danger of falling on the hard snow surface.
The hard wind slabs are rather small and can only be released in isolated cases. Transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack where hard layers are lying on a weakly bonded old snowpack are unfavourable. Such avalanche prone locations are rather rare. Skiers can release avalanches only in isolated cases.
Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise to slight moistening of the snowpack. Until the temperature falls only isolated mostly small moist and wet avalanches are possible below approximately 2600 m.
Hardly any gliding avalanches are possible, in particular on very steep grassy slopes below approximately 2400 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The weather was mild.
Below approximately 2300 m, south facing slopes: Towards its surface, the snowpack is hard and its surface has a strong melt-freeze crust.
Above the tree line snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Less snow than usual is lying. The conditions are mostly favourable. As the day progresses, moist snow slides are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The no longer entirely fresh wind slabs can be released in isolated cases, but mostly only by large additional loads,, especially at their margins. They are to be found in particular on very steep shady slopes and adjacent to ridgelines. Mostly avalanches are small.
As a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation more mostly small wet loose snow avalanches are possible, in particular on steep east, south and west facing slopes in all altitude zones. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The older wind slabs are now only very rarely prone to triggering. The old snowpack will be quite stable. It is moist and its surface has a melt-freeze crust that is strong in many cases. The high temperatures will give rise to increasing moistening of the snowpack, in particular on sunny slopes.
High altitudes and the high Alpine regions: Towards its base, the snowpack consists of faceted crystals. The snowpack will be in most cases subject to considerable local variations.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The avalanche danger will persist. Wet snow requires caution.
